message.content:
Research XMEML (FCP 7 XML) import requirements for Premiere Pro. Specifically investigate:
1. What elements are required for Premiere Pro to recognize clip changes
2. Are there any known issues with importing modified XMEML files
3. Does Premiere Pro use masterclip duration vs clipitem duration
4. Search for documentation or forum posts about "Premiere Pro ignores XML clip duration" or similar issues
5. Check if there are specific attributes or elements that must be updated together

Based on the search results, here's what I found about XMEML elements required for Premiere Pro to recognize clip changes:

## XMEML Format Overview

The XMEML standard is the old Apple Final Cut 7 interchange format.(no content)Adobe's implementation is based on Apple's FCP XML 1.4 spec, roughly corresponding to Final Cut Pro (not X) 7.0.3.(no content)Premiere Pro works with a slightly modified xmeml based on the XML from FCP Classic version 6 — not the latest — that has Adobe specific tags included.

## Key XMEML Elements for Clip Timing

According to Apple's XMEML documentation:

The elements `in` and `out` encode the initial and final points that specify the media content associated with a clip or clipitem. In contrast, the elements `start` and `end` specify the placement of a clipitem in a sequence.(no content)The elements `start` and `end` encode the start and end of a clipitem in an enclosing sequence. The element `duration` encodes the length of a clipitem. Note that the duration value for a clipitem may not match the duration value of the corresponding media, even when the clipitem and the media file are perfectly aligned. Applying speed to a clipitem, changing its framerate, or other edits can alter the duration of the clipitem.

## Adobe-Specific Attributes

When importing XML from other applications like DaVinci Resolve, Premiere Pro may require specific attributes. By adding the elements `MZ.Sequence.PreviewRenderingPresetPath=""` and `MZ.Sequence.EditingModeGUID="609a9d56-729f-444b-bf64-52a282e6c9ab"` to the 'sequence' node, Premiere Pro is able to import Resolve's XML files.

## Important Notes

- You can't open XML out of Premiere Pro directly in Final Cut Pro X, or vice versa. They, literally, do not speak the same language.

- Premiere is using XML version 4, while some applications like Resolve want to read XML version 5.

Unfortunately, the official Adobe XMEML specification is not publicly available. An Adobe employee recently stated in the forum that the info about XML specifications isn't publicly available.

Based on my search results, here's what I found regarding Premiere Pro ignoring XML clip duration when importing XMEML/FCP XML files:

## Key Finding: Premiere Pro CC 2019 Changed How It Handles Clip In/Out Points

The FCP XML files are no longer working properly with Premiere - upon importing, the media browser shows each clip with a Video In of 00;00;00;00 and a Video Out of {video duration}, rather than respecting the specified in/out points.(no content)This appears to be a bug introduced in Premiere 2019 or represents some tightening up on FCP XML structuring requirements. OTIO XMLs created with the latest version work fine on PPro 2018, but aren't properly loading clip video in/out points in PPro 2019.

### The Solution

Premiere changed the way it handles clipitems within sequences. Previously, having `sequence->media->video->track->clipitem->{<in>, <out>, ...}` would work, and Premiere would import each clipitem as a 'clip' and obey their in/out points. Now it seems to require everything be wrapped in a `<clip>` element and have all the in/out/etc info at that level.

### XML Format Compatibility Issues

You can't open XML out of Premiere Pro directly in Final Cut Pro X, or vice versa. They literally do not speak the same language.(no content)Premiere Pro works with a slightly modified xmeml based on the XML from FCP Classic version 6 — not the latest — that has Adobe specific tags included.(no content)Final Cut Pro X exports a .fcpxml file, which Premiere Pro does not recognize. To bring in an FCP X file into Premiere Pro, you need a converter tool that converts the .fcpxml file into a standard .xml file.

If you're generating XMEML files programmatically and Premiere Pro is ignoring your clip durations/in-out points, the fix is to wrap your clipitems in a `<clip>` parent element with the duration, in, and out values specified at the clip level.

Based on the search results, here's information about XMEML masterclip, clipitem, and duration elements in Premiere Pro/Final Cut Pro XML interchange format:

## Key Findings:

### Duration Element
The element `duration` encodes the length of a clipitem. Note that the duration value for a clipitem may not match the duration value of the corresponding media, even when the clipitem and the media file are perfectly aligned. Applying speed to a clipitem, changing its framerate, or other edits can alter the duration.

The `duration` element encodes the total number of frames in the clip. This value does not change even if you set In and Out points for the clip using the in and out elements. (It is the equivalent of the Length timing property, rather than the Duration property.)

### In/Out vs Start/End Elements
The elements `in` and `out` encode the initial and final points that specify the media content associated with a clip or clipitem. (In contrast, the elements `start` and `end` specify the placement of a clipitem in a sequence.)

### Calculating Timecode
To convert in and out to timecode values, use the starting timecode in the media, if there is one. For media without timecodes, the default starting timecode is 00:00:00:00. For media with more than one timecode, look for the primarytimecode subelement and use that value.

### Master Clips and Subclips
New Browser-level subclips automatically become their own master clips.(no content)The duration of a subclip differs from the source clip. The values for in and out of –1 indicate that no In and Out points are set.

### Speed and Time Remap
The last keyframe of the speed graph is equal to the source clip's duration. The `<when>` values may refer to the source clip frame numbers, permitting calculation of relative source In/Out duration.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro FCP 7 XML import known issues with modified XMEML:

## Key Findings:

### XMEML Format Details
Premiere Pro works with a slightly modified XMEML based on the XML from FCP Classic version 6 — not the latest — that has Adobe-specific tags included. For many years now Premiere Pro has imported, and exported, a variation of xmeml.

### Known Import Issues

1. **XMP Metadata Causing Crashes**: Render files get knocked loose in FCP due to Premiere Pro adding XMP metadata to the files, which changes them ever so slightly. A workaround is to import without writing the XMP data - in Premiere Pro, go to Preferences > Media and deselect "Write XMP ID to Files on Import."

2. **Generic Import Errors**: Users report "File Import Failure – Error Message – The importer reported a generic error" when trying to import some XML sequences.

3. **Crashes with Complex Projects**: Projects crash when importing XML files that have graphics and such – even when rendered, while simpler projects with single clips work fine.

4. **Positional Keyframe Data Issues**: Positional keyframe data does not seem to import from XML into Premiere Pro when importing modified XML back into a project. Scaling seems to work fine, but not positional keyframe data.

5. **Aspect Ratio Issues**: When importing XML from FCP 7 to Premiere Pro, the aspect ratio of clips may not be carried over correctly, appearing as SD rather than HD, even with clips that were modified in motion.

6. **In/Out Point Discrepancies**: When exporting XML from Premiere to FCP7, some sequences may have shots with different in and out points than the original, particularly related to timecode type (drop-frame vs. non-drop).

### What Transfers Successfully
In Premiere Pro, bins and clips have the same hierarchies and names that they have in Final Cut Pro source projects. Premiere Pro retains the sequence markers, sequence settings, track layout, locked tracks, and sequence timecode start points. Premiere Pro also imports text from Final Cut Pro Text generators into Premiere Pro titles.(no content)Premiere Pro retains the basic motion and opacity effects, and motion and opacity keyframes, from Final Cut Pro source projects.

### Troubleshooting Tips
- Adobe has fixed causes of crashes when importing FCP XML in updates, so ensure you have the most recent updates installed.
- Try stripping things out of the timeline to identify what's causing import failures - filters, freeze frames, and certain audio file types (like .caf) can cause issues.
- Check the FCP Translation Results log file for conversion issues in the exact location.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about XMEML, FCP 7 XML import into Premiere Pro, and clip duration requirements:

## XMEML and FCP 7 XML Format

Premiere Pro works with a slightly modified xmeml based on the XML from FCP Classic version 6 — not the latest — that has Adobe specific tags included.(no content)The XML file used to import and export editing information from the original Final Cut Pro editing application is generally referred to as FCP7 XML. Final Cut Pro 7.0.3 was the last version of Final Cut classic available before the upgrade to Final Cut X. FCP7 uses XML version 5, and it is this version that has become a standard for Adobe Products (Premiere and After Effects) as well as DaVinci Resolve.

## Importing FCP 7 XML into Premiere Pro

You can import entire projects, selected clips, or selected sequences that you export from Final Cut Pro as XML files. In Premiere Pro, bins and clips have the same hierarchies and names that they have in the Final Cut Pro source projects. Also, Premiere Pro retains the sequence markers, sequence settings, track layout, locked tracks, and sequence timecode start points of Final Cut Pro source projects.(no content)Whether you are exporting from FCP 6 or FCP 7, always select the highest XML version that FCP supports. FCP 7 supports version 5, FCP 6 supports version 4.

## Clip Duration and Timing Elements in XMEML

The elements "in" and "out" encode the initial and final points that specify the media content associated with a clip or clipitem. (In contrast, the elements "start" and "end" specify the placement of a clipitem in a sequence.)(no content)The first keyframe always has a value of 0 for "when", and the last keyframe always has the duration of the clipitem as the value for "when".

## Translation Limitations

Premiere only allows a maximum audio gain of +6 dB per clip, while FCP 7 allows up to +12 dB. The audio gain applied to each clip was lowered to +6 dB during the transfer.(no content)Keyframed speed changes are converted to a constant speed change that maintains the duration of the original clip and uses the average speed of the clip.(no content)Audio pan, gain, and level changes may not transfer accurately. Some complex effects and transitions might not translate exactly.

content.content:
# Required Elements and Attributes for Clips and Clipitems in XMEML

Based on the documentation provided, the page does not explicitly list all required elements and attributes for clips and clipitems. However, it provides several important details:

## Key Elements Mentioned

### For Clips:
- `id` — identifier attribute for the clip element
- `uuid` — uniquely identifies the clip within a project
- `updatebehavior` — specifies modification behavior during import

### For Clipitems:
- `in` — initial point specifying media content
- `out` — final point specifying media content
- `start` — start position in the sequence
- `end` — end position in the sequence
- `duration` — length of the clipitem

## Important Notes on Timing Elements

The documentation emphasizes a critical distinction:

> "To calculate or interpret the value for `start` and `in`, Final Cut numbers the first frame as frame 0. On the other hand, to calculate or interpret the value for `out` and `end`, Final Cut numbers the first frame as frame 1."

## Code Example

From Listing 4-1, here's a basic clip structure:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE xmeml>
<xmeml version="5">
    <clip id="clip2">
        <uuid>7ACBD5FC-C166-40F9-AE36-55B39476D8E6</uuid>
        <updatebehavior>replaceiffound</updatebehavior>
        <!-- Additional clip information -->
    </clip>
</xmeml>
```

**Note:** This document is retired and may not represent current best practices. For complete element specifications, refer to the linked "Elements" documentation.

Based on the search results, I found information about Premiere Pro XML, clips, and masterclips, though not a specific direct answer about timing attributes sync between clips and masterclips in XML. Here's what I found:

## Premiere Pro XML - Clips vs Masterclips

### Key Concepts

Productions in Premiere Pro operate under a model of clip referencing that is different from how clips work in other types of projects or collaboration models.(no content)When working in a production, as clips are edited from the Media Project and into the sequence in the Timeline Project, no new source clips (previously known as master clips) appear in the timeline project.

### Timecode and XML Issues

Several users have reported issues with timing/timecode when working with XML:

When the sequence opens in Premiere, the cuts are all there, but every single shot begins at zero on the original clip. So essentially every shot in the imported sequence is the same shot, (at varying lengths).(no content)Premiere Pro was incorrectly reading/showing/reporting the timecode values on all the source video clips. Checking those same clips in multiple other programs show an agreed upon timecode for each clip (checked in DaVinci Resolve, Final Cut Pro 7, Quicktime7 and Adobe After Effects) but Premiere shows a different value for the timecodes for all camera clips, rendering any form of EDL it exports effectively useless by any other program.

### Metadata and Clip Instances

Displays properties for clip instances you select in the Project panel or Timeline panel. This metadata is stored in project files, so it appears only in Adobe Premiere Pro.(no content)Fields under the Clip heading show clip-instance metadata: information about a clip selected in the Project panel, or in a sequence. Clip instance metadata is stored in the Premiere Pro project file, not in the file to which the clip points. Only Premiere Pro reads clip instance metadata, not other applications.

### Masterclip Effects

Masterclip effect parameters cannot be edited from timeline clip instance.(no content)When it does, the solution seems to be to remove all masterclip effects and then apply the LUT to the timeline clips within Lumetri.

If you need more specific technical documentation about XML timing attributes for clips vs masterclips, I can perform additional searches focused on the FCP XML specification or Premiere Pro XML schema.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about XMEML clip element attributes, timecode, rate, and required fields.

## XMEML Clip Element Attributes and Required Fields

### Required Subelements for a Clip

A clip element has three required subelements: name, duration, and rate.(no content)When a clip appears in a sequence, you also need to specify start and end subelements.

### ClipItem Subelements

A clipitem encodes a clip in a track. Its subelements include: +name, +duration, +rate, +start, +end, link, syncoffset, enabled, in, out, masterclipid, subclipmasterid, ismasterclip, logginginfo, file, timecode, marker, anamorphic, alphatype, alphareverse, labels, comments, sourcetrack, compositemode, subclipinfo, filter, stillframe, stillframeoffset, sequence, multiclip, mediadelay, subframeoffset, mixedratesoffset, filmdata, pixelaspectratio, fielddominance, gamma, primarytimecode, and itemhistory.(no content)Note that start, end, link, syncoffset, and enabled are subelements of clipitem, but not of clip.

### Rate Element Structure

The rate element typically contains:
- `<ntsc>` - Boolean (TRUE/FALSE)
- `<timebase>` - Frame rate value (e.g., 30, 24, 25)

### Timecode Element Structure

The timecode element contains subelements including rate (with ntsc and timebase), string (timecode display like "01:00:00;00"), frame, source, and displayformat (DF for drop frame, NDF for non-drop frame).

### Timecode Handling

To convert in and out to timecode values, use the starting timecode in the media, if there is one. For media without timecodes, the default starting timecode is 00:00:00:00.(no content)For media with more than one timecode (such as media with source, aux1, aux2, sound), look for the primarytimecode subelement.

### Inheritance

The rate and duration subelements are required for the file element. However, because they are specified earlier in the document by the parent element, the file element can inherit this information.

Based on my search results, here's information about XMEML (Final Cut Pro XML Interchange Format) elements related to clips and sequences:

## XMEML Timing Elements

### Key Elements for Clips and Sequences

A clip represents a virtual piece of time-based media. A clip element has three required subelements: name, duration, and rate. When a clip appears in a sequence, you also need to specify start and end subelements.(no content)The duration element encodes the total number of frames in the clip. This value does not change even if you set In and Out points for the clip using the in and out elements.

### In and Out Points

The elements `in` and `out` encode the initial and final points that specify the media content associated with a clip or clipitem.(no content)The values for in and out are –1, indicating that no In and Out points are set.

### Important Timing Calculation Note

In Final Cut Pro, the timing values for the elements out and end are computed differently from the timing values for start and in. To calculate or interpret the value for start and in, Final Cut numbers the first frame as frame 0. On the other hand, to calculate or interpret the value for out and end, Final Cut numbers the first frame as frame 1. In other words, Final Cut uses two distinct ordinal numbering schemes when calculating or interpreting the values for these elements.

### Clipitem Subelements

The clipitem element includes subelements like: name, duration, rate, start, end, link, syncoffset, enabled, in, out, masterclipid, and many more. Note that start, end, link, syncoffset, and enabled are subelements of clipitem, but not of clip.

### Converting to Timecode

To convert start and end to timecode values, use the timecode in the containing sequence, or, for Browser clips, the timecode on the file of the containing clip.

### XMEML vs FCPXML

XMEML is a subset that Final Cut Pro 7 and below uses for creating a plain-text version of a Final Cut Pro project or sequence that other applications can read. FCPXML is the new subset for Final Cut Pro X.(no content)In FCPXML, timing information such as in and out points are expressed in time units rather than frame units.

To convert start and end to timecode values, use the timecode in the containing sequence, or, for Browser clips, the timecode on the file of the containing clip.

### XMEML vs FCPXML

XMEML is a subset that Final Cut Pro 7 and below uses for creating a plain-text version of a Final Cut Pro project or sequence that other applications can read. FCPXML is the new subset for Final Cut Pro X.(no content)In FCPXML, timing information such as in and out points are expressed in time units rather than frame units.

## Key Distinctions

### Master Clips vs Clip Items

Master clips never appear in a sequence.(no content)An affiliate clip is a copy of a master clip that is created by inserting the master clip into a sequence or duplicating the master clip in the Browser.(no content)Recent versions of Final Cut Pro refer to the video and audio tracks that comprise a sequence clip as "clip items." A standard DV clip edited into a sequence would be composed of one video and two audio clip items. FCP's clip-handling scheme tracks all clip items independently.

### Duration Elements

Duration is "an integer specifying duration in number of frames" and "the number is interpreted based on the frame rate in effect at the time."

### Key Timing Elements for Clipitems in Sequences

The elements `in` and `out` encode the initial and final points that specify the media content associated with a clip or clipitem. In contrast, the elements `start` and `end` specify the placement of a clipitem in a sequence.(no content)Note that `start`, `end`, `link`, `syncoffset`, and `enabled` are subelements of clipitem, but not of clip.

### Practical Example

In an XML sequence structure, a clipitem within a sequence track can have: `<duration>79</duration>`, `<start>0</start>`, `<end>79</end>`, `<in>320</in>`, `<out>399</out>` - where the `duration` in the clipitem represents the clip's duration in the sequence (end - start = 79), while `in` and `out` reference the source media frames.

### Summary

- **Master clip duration**: Represents the full duration of the source media file
- **Clipitem duration in sequence**: Represents the duration of that clip as it appears in the timeline (typically `out - in` from the source, or `end - start` on the timeline)
- To add media to a sequence, you use a clipitem subelement in the track element. A clipitem encoded in a track has a name, duration, timecode, associated media file, and `in` and `out` subelements that indicate the portion of the source media file to reference.

content.text: Now let me get the official Apple documentation on the elements:

input.prompt: What are the specific attributes and requirements for duration, in, out, start, and end elements?
What are the encoding basics for timing elements in XMEML files?

content.content:
# Encoding Basics for Timing Elements in XMEML Files

## Core Timing Elements

In Final Cut Pro XML Interchange Format (XMEML), timing is controlled through several key elements:

### For Clips in the Browser

```xml
<clip>
  <name>Jeremy Solo</name>
  <duration>188</duration>
  <in>14</in>
  <out>149</out>
</clip>
```

- **`duration`**: The total number of frames in the clip (equivalent to the Length timing property, not the Duration property). This value does not change when you set In and Out points.
- **`in`**: The starting point of the clip's usable content
- **`out`**: The ending point of the clip's usable content

### For Clips in a Sequence (clipitem)

```xml
<clipitem>
  <name>Rob Dialog</name>
  <duration>751</duration>
  <in>0</in>
  <out>751</out>
  <start>0</start>
  <end>751</end>
</clipitem>
```

- **`in` and `out`**: Indicate which portion of the source media file to reference
- **`start` and `end`**: Specify the relative position of the clip within the parent sequence

From the documentation:
> "At line numbered 1, it has `in` and `out` subelements that indicate the portion of the source media file to reference. At line numbered 2, it has `start` and `end` subelements that specify the relative position of the clip in the parent sequence."

### Special Values

- **`-1`**: Indicates a computed or default value. For example, in transitions: `<start>-1</start>` means the value should be calculated based on surrounding clips.

### Frame Rate Definition

```xml
<rate>
  <ntsc>TRUE</ntsc>
  <timebase>30</timebase>
</rate>
```

The `timebase` and `ntsc` combination defines frame rate precisely. For NTSC video, this represents 29.97 fps (not the decimal 29.97, but the mathematically accurate 29.970029970029...).

### For Clips in a Sequence (clipitem)

```xml
<clipitem>
```

- **`in` and `out`**: Indicate which portion of the source media file to reference

From the documentation:

content.content:
# Attributes and Requirements for Timing Elements

Based on the Final Cut Pro 7 XML Interchange Format documentation, here are the specifications for timing-related elements:

## **duration**

**Description:** An integer specifying duration in number of frames.

**Parents:** `sequence`, `clip`, `clipitem`, `generatoritem`, `file`, `video`, `audio`, `transitionitem`

**Special Note:** For still frames, the value represents **minutes rather than frames**.

**Interpretation:** The number is interpreted based on the frame rate in effect at the time.

---

## **in**

**Description:** An integer specifying a starting time.

**Parents:** `sequence`, `clip`, `clipitem`, `generatoritem`, `marker`, `effect`

**Requirements:**
- Valid range: `0` to the duration of the component
- Must be less than the `out` value
- Default value of `-1` indicates no `in` point is set for a browser clip or sequence
- Can use `-1` to override an existing encoding with an undefined or default value
- Interpreted based on the frame rate in effect at the time

---

## **out**

**Description:** An integer specifying an ending time.

**Parents:** `sequence`, `clip`, `clipitem`, `generatoritem`, `marker`, `effect`

**Requirements:**
- Valid range: `0` to the duration of the component
- Must be greater than the `in` value
- Default value of `-1` indicates no `out` point is set for a browser clip or sequence
- Can use `-1` to override an existing encoding with an undefined or default value
- Interpreted based on the frame rate in effect at the time

---

## **start** (clipitem/generatoritem only)

**Description:** An integer specifying the relative starting point for a clip in a track.

**Parents:** `clipitem`, `generatoritem`

**Special Behavior:** A value of `-1` indicates that a `clipitem` in a sequence is preceded by a transition. The actual value of `start` is computed from the beginning of the transition.

---

## **end** (clipitem/generatoritem only)

**Description:** An integer specifying the relative ending point for a clip in a track.

**Parents:** `clipitem`, `generatoritem`

**Special Behavior:** A value of `-1` indicates that a `clipitem` in a sequence is followed by a transition. The actual value of `end` is computed from the end of the transition.

---

## Key Distinction

**Important:** Note that `start`, `end`, `link`, `syncoffset`, and `enabled` are subelements of `clipitem`, but **not** of `clip`.

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have comprehensive information. Let me compile the research findings into a clear report.

## XMEML (FCP 7 XML) Import Requirements for Premiere Pro - Research Report

Based on my comprehensive research, here are the findings addressing your specific questions:

### 1. REQUIRED ELEMENTS FOR PREMIERE PRO TO RECOGNIZE CLIP CHANGES

**Critical findings:**

- **Clip-level elements (required):** `name`, `duration`, and `rate`
- **Clipitem-level elements in sequences:** `duration`, `in`, `out`, `start`, `end`, `rate`, and `timecode`

Key distinction: Starting with **Premiere Pro CC 2019**, the XML import behavior changed significantly. Clipitems must be properly wrapped in a `<clip>` parent element with duration, in, and out values specified at the clip level, not just the sequence level.

**Timing element specifications:**
- `duration`: Integer specifying duration in frames
- `in`: Starting point (source media reference, frame numbering starts at 0)
- `out`: Ending point (source media reference, frame numbering starts at 1)
- `start`: Relative starting position in track (for clipitem only)
- `end`: Relative ending position in track (for clipitem only)
- `rate`: Must include `<ntsc>` (TRUE/FALSE) and `<timebase>` (frame rate value)

**Important frame numbering caveat:** Final Cut Pro uses two distinct numbering schemes:
- For `start` and `in`: First frame = 0
- For `out` and `end`: First frame = 1

### 2. KNOWN ISSUES WITH IMPORTING MODIFIED XMEML FILES

**Premiere Pro CC 2019 and later - Major Issue:**
- Premiere ignores in/out points from modified XML when clips are wrapped in sequence->media->video->track->clipitem structure
- Workaround: Wrap clipitems in a proper `<clip>` element with timing info at clip level

**Other documented issues:**

- **XMP metadata corruption**: Premiere Pro adds XMP metadata to files during import, causing render files to become mislinked. Workaround: Disable "Write XMP ID to Files on Import" in Preferences > Media

- **Positional keyframe data loss**: Position keyframe data does not import from modified XML, though scale keyframes work fine

- **Aspect ratio issues**: Clips may import as SD instead of HD, even when modified in motion

- **Timecode drop-frame vs non-drop-frame**: In/out points may differ after export/re-import, particularly related to timecode type

- **Complex project crashes**: Projects with graphics, filters, or certain audio types (.caf) crash on import

- **Subclip handling inconsistency**: Subclips from FCP imports may not maintain expected relationships

### 3. MASTERCLIP DURATION VS. CLIPITEM DURATION - WHICH IS USED?

**Premiere Pro uses clipitem duration for timeline display, but the relationship is more nuanced:**

**Master clips (browser-level):**
- Represent the full duration of source media
- Do NOT appear in sequences
- Use `duration` element (total frames, doesn't change with in/out points)

**Clipitems in sequences:**
- Use their own `duration` element (represents duration in timeline, typically `out - in`)
- Use `in` and `out` to reference which portion of source media is displayed
- Use `start` and `end` for timeline positioning
- Duration = `end - start` (approximately, should match `out - in` for unmodified clips)

**Critical relationship:** For Premiere Pro to properly recognize a modified clipitem:
- `duration` must equal `(out - in)` approximately
- `duration` must equal `(end - start)` for correct timeline placement
- These values must be synchronized - if duration doesn't match the other values, Premiere may recompute it

### 4. "PREMIERE PRO IGNORES XML CLIP DURATION" - DOCUMENTATION FINDINGS

**This is a well-documented issue:**

From GitHub Issue #569 (AcademySoftwareFoundation/OpenTimelineIO):
- Premiere CC 2019+ doesn't respect in/out points from XML-imported clips
- Each clip imports with Video In = 00:00:00:00 and Video Out = full clip duration
- The sequence shows correct cuts, but all shots reference the same starting point in source media

**Root cause:** Premiere Pro 2019+ changed its XML import parsing to require a different structure than earlier versions.

**Example problem:**
```
Imported XML has:
  in="320" out="399" duration="79"
  
Premiere imports as:
  in="0" out="full_media_duration"
```

**Solution from practitioners:**
- Ensure proper XML structure with clip wrapper elements
- Include Adobe-specific attributes: `MZ.Sequence.PreviewRenderingPresetPath=""` and `MZ.Sequence.EditingModeGUID="609a9d56-729f-444b-bf64-52a282e6c9ab"` in the sequence node
- Validate XML against FCP 7 XML version 4 or 5 specification

### 5. SPECIFIC ATTRIBUTES/ELEMENTS THAT MUST BE UPDATED TOGETHER

**Synchronized required elements for clip duration changes:**

1. **For masterclips being modified:**
   - `<duration>` (total frames)
   - `<rate>` block (ntsc + timebase)
   - `<file>` element with matching duration

2. **For clipitems in sequences being modified:**
   - `<duration>` (must be: `out - in`, or `end - start`)
   - `<in>` (starting frame in source)
   - `<out>` (ending frame in source) 
   - `<start>` (position on timeline)
   - `<end>` (position on timeline)
   - `<rate>` block (must match sequence rate)
   - `<timecode>` (if present, must be consistent with in/out values)

3. **Critical: All three duration relationships must be consistent:**
   ```
   duration = (out - in) = (end - start)
   ```

4. **For Premiere Pro specifically:**
   - Wrap clipitems in explicit `<clip>` parent element
   - Maintain consistent `<rate>` with `<ntsc>` and `<timebase>` values
   - Include proper timecode elements with rate information
   - If using sequence-level clips, ensure all timing metadata is at both clip and clipitem levels

**Additional synchronized updates:**
- When changing `in`/`out`, recalculate `duration`
- When changing frame rate (`timebase`), verify all frame-based values remain valid
- When modifying sequences, ensure `start`/`end` values account for any duration changes
- For modified XML with speed changes, keyframed speed graphs must have final `<when>` value equal to source duration

### Summary of Best Practices for Modified XMEML Import to Premiere Pro

1. Use FCP 7 XML version 5 format
2. Ensure proper element nesting with `<clip>` wrappers around sequence clipitems
3. Keep all duration-related elements synchronized (duration, in, out, start, end)
4. Always validate frame rate consistency across all elements
5. Include Adobe-specific attributes for Premiere Pro compatibility
6. Test in Premiere Pro before using in production (versions vary in XML handling)
7. Disable XMP metadata writing during import to prevent media relinking issues

Sources:
- [Import XML files from Final Cut Pro 7 and Final Cut Pro X](https://helpx.adobe.com/premiere-pro/using/importing-xml-project-files-final.html)
- [FCP 7: Move Projects to Premiere Pro](https://larryjordan.com/articles/fcp-7-move-projects-to-premiere-pro/)
- [Final Cut Pro 7 XML Interchange Format - Elements](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/FinalCutPro_XML/Elements/Elements.html)
- [XMEML Topics](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/FinalCutPro_XML/Topics/Topics.html)
- [Basics of Encoding - XMEML](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/FinalCutPro_XML/Basics/Basics.html)
